executive_summary: Farm animal feed producers have enjoyed soaring revenue over the past five years, though revenue has begun to taper off from its peak in 2022. A major drought across the continental US severely cut crop yields in 2020 and 2021, pushing feed costs to historic highs, which forced feed manufacturers to up prices to preserve profitability. Imports skyrocketed in 2021 to supplement domestic production but have remained minuscule as a share of domestic demand. Overall meat consumption has continued to expand, despite slumps in beef consumption. Thanks to the industry's ability to pass on most heightened input costs to downstream industries, industry-wide revenue has been growing at a CAGR of 2.9% over the past five years and is expected to total $46.4 billion in 2023, when revenue will sink by an estimated 2.3%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Drought Fueled a Surge in Prices
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The Western, Midwestern and Northeastern US were all hit by a severe drought that began in the summer of 2020 and lasted through the first half of 2021. Droughts and other extreme weather conditions severely cut crop yields, which pushes up prices. The price of feed spiked 13.6% in 2021, while the price of corn skyrocketed 54.3% the same year. Feed manufacturers responded by raising prices, though fierce competition limits each producer's pricing power.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Imports Surged to Make Up for Lost Domestic Production
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Imports of finished farm animal feed jumped a massive 29.2% in 2021 as expensive input costs for US feed manufacturers left them unable to compete with overseas alternatives. Feed from a variety of countries flooded into the US market and undercut US feed suppliers, though long-term contracts and fast delivery times helped domestic producers remain the primary suppliers of domestic demand. Import penetration rose in 2021 but has begun to slump. Even still, imports have consistently accounted for less than 3.0% of domestic demand.
Rising revenue stemming from heightened prices helps the industry manage fixed costs, but supply chain disruptions following the COVID-19 pandemic

The Russian invasion of Ukraine has exacerbated volatility in feed costs; the two nations make up over a quarter of the world's wheat production, according to the New York Times. Farm animal feed producers have struggled to manage production capacity amid extremely volatile commodity prices and expensive transportation costs, leading to strained profit.

Despite the prevalence of veganism and other alternative diets, per capita consumption of pork, dairy and poultry has climbed over the past five years. While health concerns are pushing many consumers away from beef, a growing population is continuing to push beef cattle production's head counts upwards.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Falling Feed Prices Will Bring Down Revenue
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The most significant driver of the industry's downward trajectory is falling feed prices, which will drop almost every year through the end of 2028. Competitive pressure will push farm animal feed producers to drop prices as input costs decline, bringing down revenue. Weather patterns are unpredictable, though, and surprise harsh conditions can restart the cycle at any time.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Global Demand Rises, But US Producers Are Left Out
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The USDA predicts global meat consumption to double by 2050 as demand for meat is bolstered by countries like China, India and Indonesia. Because meat is generally more expensive than other food alternatives, meat consumption typically increases when incomes climb. McKinsey & Company estimates that 30.0% of China's population will be in or above the upper-middle income range by 2030, a sharp rise from its current 20.0%. Exports are forecast to stagnate, though, as US feed producers have historically been unable to gain a solid foothold in overseas markets and foreign feed manufacturers will remain the primary suppliers of growing demand.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: U.S. Producers Gain Back Domestic Demand
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Imports will sink from previous highs over the next five years as the depreciation of the US dollar promotes domestic feed producers. The declining trade-weighted index will make US farm animal feed comparatively cheaper than foreign feed, allowing domestic producers to regain some share of domestic demand. Still, imports account for a very low percentage of domestic demand, and expanding markets won't offset declining feed costs.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Consumer Preference Changes Limit Demand for the Industry's Feed
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Consumer preference will continue to shift to meat raised on organic feed. Grass-fed and grass-finished beef will become more popular, cutting demand for the industry's corn- and soy-based high-calorie meals. Consumers have become increasingly skeptical of antibiotics and growth hormones in farm animal feed, and larger farm animal feed manufacturers will need to operate multiple product lines in response.

industry_definition: This industry includes animal feed manufacturers that make food for livestock. Producers use remnants of flour milling, sugar production and other food processing as ingredient inputs to animal feed.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level low - increasing

key_trends: Feed manufacturers compete on price. Because animal feed is considered relatively homogenous, providing affordable prices is key to retaining customers and avoiding losing business to competitors.

Nutritional content helps differentiate feed. Feed producers not included in this industry can often offer lower prices, so investing in R&D to create high-value farm animal feed can help justify slightly higher prices.

Mounting feed costs have elevated industry revenue. Severe drought limited crop yields in 2020 and 2021, leading to historic highs for the price of feed. Farm animal feed manufacturers have been able to pass most costs downstream through heightened prices, though input costs have started to taper off.
Supply chain issues have cut profit. Volatility in input costs and major shortages from the Russia-Ukraine war have forced many feed manufacturers to absorb expenses and suffer reduced profit.

Consumption is on the rise. Despite the prevalence of alternative diets, mounting per capita poultry, pork and dairy consumption are making up for sinking beef consumption and securing demand for animal feed. Meat consumption is growing overseas, as well, but stagnating exports will leave US feed producers out of foreign growth.
Major companies are reporting slim profit. Purina, Cargill and CHS all are contending with profit less than 2.7%.

All major companies are in the Plains. Purina and CHS are both headquartered in Missouri and Minnesota, respectively, while Cargill's head office is in Wichita, Kansas. Jon Nash, Cargill's North America President, says the company wants to make Wichita the "Silicon Valley of Protein."

Feed producers are heavily regulated. The ingredients used in farm animal feed are governed by a swath of laws that aim to prevent contamination and negative effects on animal and human health. Product labels are also closely supervised, and infractions can come with hefty fines.

The industry receives little government assistance. A lack of tariff laws may give feed producers access to more affordable imports, but the industry mostly relies on the AFIA, a strong trade association that creates a community and lobby for its members.
Profit is extremely slim. Volatile commodity prices, in addition to intense competition that limited the industry's pricing power, have left feed manufacturers with compressed profit.
Other costs are on the rise. Livestock farmers are becoming increasingly concerned with the nutritional value of feed, and feed

market_segmentation.segment_description: Despite many switching to vegan-friendly alternative dairy products, per capita dairy consumption has climbed over the past five years. Beef consumption is on the decline, though, as many consumers look to seafood or chicken as healthier or more humane alternatives. Many worry about the potential link between red meat and heart disease, as well as genetic modification.

Per capita poultry consumption has had strong growth over the past five years, climbing at a CAGR of 0.9%. Egg consumption has climbed at a slower rate than poultry consumption but is forecast to grow at a faster pace through the end of 2028.

Farmers who raise hogs and pigs for meat production account for a relatively small portion of revenue. Animal feed manufacturers catering to the swine farming market need to provide high-quality, nutrient-dense feeds that support the healthy growth and development of pigs, while also being cost-effective. This market bumped up in 2020 as China's national herd was halved by African swine flu and pork exports boomed.

Farm animal feed manufacturers also sell feed to sheep, llama, goat and horse farmers, among others. The vast amount of animals included in this segment leads it to account for a sizeable portion of revenue, even though cattle, chicken and swine are the three most popular species.

products_and_services.product_description: Cattle Feed Varies by Specialization. Growing consumer preference for grass-fed beef has limited demand from beef cattle farmers, while dairy farmers continue to prefer calorie-dense corn and soybean feed. Still, many grass-fed beef producers are able to adhere to labeling laws by feeding cattle grass through the stocking stage and finishing them on high-calorie feed.

Poultry Feed Continues to Make Up the Largest Segment. Chickens and turkeys rely on feed, as they don't graze on grass. Chickens are especially suited to consume insect meal, which is becoming a popular and more affordable protein supplement. Expanding production capacities continue to fuel this segment's dominance.

tier_2_suppliers: Wheat, Barley & Sorghum Farming in the US
Corn, Wheat & Soybean Wholesaling in the US
tier_1_buyers: Beef Cattle Production in the US
Hog & Pig Farming in the US
tier_2_buyers: Farm Supplies Wholesaling in the US
Chicken & Turkey Meat Production in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Farm animal feed producers generate revenue by selling feed either directly to farms or to wholesalers. As the price of feed rises, so does industry revenue, assuming the volume of feed sold doesn't change. The price of feed is expected to decline in 2023, posing a threat to the industry.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Because of drought in 2020 and 2021 that severely undercut crop yields, imports of animal feed products skyrocketed 29.2% in 2021. Imports have returned to a pre-drought percentage of domestic demand in the years since, though.

While concerns of the link between red meat and heart disease have dampened beef consumption, rising poultry and pork consumption have made up for losses in beef consumption. Rising demand has upped production capacities from livestock farms, many of which source feed from overseas.

international_trade_points.trade_title: An Appreciating Dollar Stalled Export Growth
international_trade_points.trade_description: Widespread inflation in many countries from postpandemic recovery and the Russian invasion of Ukraine heavily shifted the trade-weighted index (TWI) in 2022. The rising TWI made US feed comparatively more expensive than foreign alternatives, leading exports to stagnate over the past five years.

Canada and Mexico account for the first and third-largest sources of international demand, respectively, which can be explained by the Geographic proximity and shared borders with the United States. The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) reduces trade barriers between the three nations and promotes export growth.

business_locations.location_description: The Plains region has the highest percentage of establishments (around 35%) compared to its population percentage (around 20%). This indicates a significant concentration of farm animal feed production establishments in the Plains region relative to its population. Because of favorable weather conditions and cheap land prices, the Plains region contains a massive amount of the nation's farms. Feed manufacturers located near corn and soybean farmers can save on input costs, helping them offer lower prices to buyers. Many livestock farmers are also located in the Plains, and feed manufacturers located close by can provide fast delivery in addition to lower prices. The industry's top three companies are all headquartered in the Plains.

Because nearly a quarter of the nation lives in the Southeast region, the region is a hotbed for many manufacturing industries. Feed manufacturers buy byproducts from other manufacturing industries for reprocessing into animal feed, so locating in the Southeast provides access to many key inputs. Generally favorable weather conditions also promote farming in the region, though other regions are still more popular.

While the Great Lakes region has long been a hub for several major manufacturing industries, it also is home to many farms. Major company Archer Daniels Midland is headquartered in Decatur, Illinois, and operates many production facilities in the region.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The FSMA requires feed manufacturers to implement preventive controls to minimize the risk of contamination as well as establish hazard analysis and risk-based preventive controls for farm animal feed. It also requires them to register with the FDA and comply with the latest record-keeping requirements.

The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) seeks to promote and protect public health by monitoring products for continued safety. The FDA's Food, Drug and Cosmetic (FD&C) Act and Fair Packaging and Labeling Act established standards for the production and labeling of farm animal feed. The Nutrition Labeling and Education Act and Food Ingredient Safety Program review claims about the ingredients and nutritional content farm animal feed producers make, and those out of compliance can be subject to hefty fines or shutdown.

regulations_points.regulation_title: FDA CURRENT GOOD MANUFACTURING PRACTICE REQUIREMENTS
regulations_points.regulation_description: In 2017, the FDA issued a guidance document meant for facilities subject to the Preventive Controls for Animal Food rule that clarifies and supports existing sanitation and packaging laws. Current Good Manufacturing Practice (CGMP) regulations are preventive measures farm animal feed producers need to comply with to avoid contamination during production, which can be harmful to animal health and the health of humans who go on to eat contaminated meat.

regulations_points.regulation_title: HAZARD ANALYSIS AND CRITICAL CONTROL POINTS
regulations_points.regulation_description: The FDA's HACCP system is a science-based approach used to identify and control hazards in the production process of animal feed products. It requires manufacturers to conduct a hazard analysis, identify critical control points, establish control measures and monitor the process to ensure safety.

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has issues several pieces of legislation farm animal feed producers need to comply with. The Clean Water Act mandates any facility that discharges waste to have a National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit.

The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) enforces strict standards and guidelines that govern the quality and safety of all vegetables, meat, poultry and eggs manufactured in the country. The USDA's Food Safety and Inspection Service has issued legislation that requires food-processing facilities to develop a written set of sanitation standard-operating procedures (SSOPs) that ensure pre-operational sanitary conditions are satisfied. Once written, SSOPs are reviewed by USDA officials.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is mature, increasing barriers to entry.
Low and steady industry assistance level.
High and steady level of competition.

basis_points.basis_description: Feed manufacturers compete on price as animal feed is considered relatively homogenous.
Nutritional content helps differentiate feed from lower-priced competitors.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Major feed manufacturers with solid reputations are better able to retain clients.
Benefitting from economies of scale is essential due to low per-unit sale prices.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases Make Up the Bulk of Revenue
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases are estimated to account for 61.7% of revenue in 2023, down from 66.6% in 2018. Animal feed manufacturers buy corn, soybeans and other feedstocks from farmers, as well as byproducts from food processing industries. Feed producers also purchase plastic packaging and paperboard containers to transport finished feed.

Profit is estimated to account for 2.7% of revenue in 2023, down from 4.2% in 2018. High volatility from droughts and supply chain shortages have pushed input costs upwards and compressed profit. Rising per-employee pay and increasing R&D investment have also limited profit.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Other Costs Help Establish Sales Relationships
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Other costs make up an estimated 27.7% of revenue in 2023, up from 21.4% in 2018. The amount of money feed producers spend on selling, general costs and administrative fees change from company to company, as some already have lucrative contracts with key buyers and don't need to invest heavily in acquiring new ones. This segment also included research and development expenses, which have become more significant as livestock farmers continue to seek more nutritional animal feed.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Capital intensity is moderate because feed manufacturers purchase input costs and rely on machines that require upkeep, so entrants will need to contend with a moderate level of capital intensity.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Revenue is tied to commodity prices
volatility_points.volatility_description: Farm animal feed manufacturers shift the price of their end products in line with changing input costs. The price of key inputs, like corn, wheat, soybeans and other grains, has been extremely volatile over the past five years as a drought in 2020, alongside floods and other unpredictable weather conditions, made supply unreliable. Supply chain disruptions from the COVID-19 pandemic and the grain shortage stemming from the war between Russia and Ukraine have exacerbated existing fluctuations.

Similar to crop production, livestock industries can be unpredictable. Disease outbreaks, like bovine spongiform encephalopathy (mad-cow disease), can decimate livestock populations and significantly cut demand from the industry's buyers. On the other hand, demand from US swine production shot up over the past five years as China dealt with a devastating outbreak of African swine flu that culled nearly half of the national herd.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Farm animal feed manufacturers are responding to the demands of livestock farmers by providing calorie-dense animal feed. By using soy and other high-energy feedstocks, feed producers can help farmers fatten up livestock in preparation for slaughter. Feed manufacturers are also incorporating probiotics, enzymes and growth hormones to maximize per-head yield, though the use of these is subject to additional regulations.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Sustainable feed inputs are becoming popular
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Concerns about soybean meal and other inputs' sustainability have led some feed producers to look to alternative inputs. Insect meal, which is rich in protein and amino acids, has become a popular supplemental protein source for farm animal feed. The use of insect meal has the potential to reduce the environmental impact of animal agriculture by reducing the reliance on traditional protein sources that require large amounts of land, water, and other resources.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the agricultural sector?
FAQs.answer: The price companies receive for their product heavily depends on the market price of animal feed.

FAQs.question: Have exports offered an opportunity for your company?
FAQs.answer: The US is a net exporter of farm animal feed and exports are an increasingly attractive option for companies in this industry.

FAQs.question: Is your company located near crop growing industry hubs?
FAQs.answer: Most companies are located near major crop growing areas, especially for corn and soybeans, in order to minimize shipping costs.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry use commoditized crops, such as corn and soybeans, as inputs, so they are quite exposed to volatile input prices.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to safeguard your company's proprietary information?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry regularly file patents for new, specific formulations of feed or supplements.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: While some companies have made significant capital investments towards automation, wages continue to rise.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: The American Feed Industry Association (AFIA) is the main interest group representing this industry.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry face scrutiny from the EPA, the FDA and the US Department of Agriculture.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected profit margins over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: Companies, especially major players like Cargill, have seen profit margins climb in the face of falling corn prices.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: The company's profits are competitive, reflecting efficient operations and market demand. However, a detailed comparison with competitors' margins requires in-depth analysis of industry benchmarks and financial data.

FAQs.question: Are you able to leverage economies of scale? What is your budget for expanding operations?
FAQs.answer: The scale and breadth of production largely determines marginal costs while also impacting the volume a producer is able to supply.

FAQs.question: How much of your production is devoted to premium products? Do you spend on marketing to position your products as top-quality?
FAQs.answer: Products that specifically target animal health or address specific conditions of an animal's life cycle demand a premium.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain product quality? Do you have systems in place to keep standards high and continually updating?
FAQs.answer: The industry operators must comply with constantly changing USDA regulations regarding health and safety.

FAQs.question: What percentage of demand comes from the US Farm Supplies Wholesaling industry?
FAQs.answer: The US Farm Supplies Wholesaling industry is the largest market for animal food producers.

FAQs.question: Do your suppliers raise prices when feed costs increase? What portion of the added expenses are you able to pass on to your own customers?
FAQs.answer: Fluctuation in domestic feed prices will affect the revenue that feed producers generate.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor trends in meat consumption? How has your revenue been affected by healthy eating trends?
FAQs.answer: The shift toward healthier diets has slowed red meat consumption but has driven demand for leaner poultry meats.
